Cooling-Down procedure

Leak check DU \(\to\) Hall-C

  • Please leak check the DU (Dilution Unit) flanges every time that you open them to air.
    • Typically, between two consecutive runs, you are forced to unplug the condenser KF-10 bellow and the still ISO-K100, both on top of the cryostat.
  • The DU leak check should be performed at room temperature.

    The recommended leak rate should be \(< 10^{-9} \ \rm{mbar*l/s}\).

Rinse the DU

  • To achieve ideal leak rate, you can rinse the DU circulation path with high-purity N2 (Nitrogen).
    • Because after years of using, a large amount of He (Helium) remains inside the pipes.
    • The high-purity nitrogen could come from the LN2 (Liquid Nitrogen) dewar.
  1. Firstly, clean around v10 and v11.
  2. Then put 100 mbar of N2 in the still, through
    • \(\rm{VENT1 \to v11 \to v6 \to v7 \to BYPASSofSTILL}\) .
  3. And then use ROOTS pump \(\to\) AUX (auxiliary) pump to pump it.
    • This process should then be repeated 3 times.
    • The leak rate should seem to be improved.

IVC pumping

  • Inside IVC (Inner Vacuum Chamber), there are extremely delicate crystals that should be either flushed with high-purity N2 or be pumped.
    • Because the surface of the crystal is extremely deliquescent, nitrogen can help absorb moisture and pumping can remove it.
  • To pump IVC, you can use the turbo \(\to\) leak detector or the turbo \(\to\) AUX.
    • Whichever you choose, make sure you have a certain vacuum level before turning on the turbo.
    • It is always good to use Pman (the red pressure sensor which we looted from CUORE) to monitor the pressure.
      • Actually in Hall-C, we use a T to allow us to monitor both IVC and OVC.

DU pumping

Before operation, the IVC is being pumped with turbo and leak detector.

  • We closed the valve on the IVC and turned off the turbo.
  • While waiting for the turbo to decelerate, we pump the cryostat from the back end with the BYPASSofSTILL.
  • After that, we opened the valve of the condenser line, and pumped from the front end.
  • We used the BYPASS A and B to clean up the ROOTS pump.
  • We opened the QSB valve in front of the ROOTS pump, allowing the cryostat to be pumped by the ROOTS pump.

The path of reference

  • \(\rm{v12 + v13 \to ROTARY \to G4}\)
    • The right side of valves 12 and 13 are pumped by the ROTARY pump, and the output is accumulated at G4;
  • \(\rm{still \to QSB \to ROOTS \to BYPASS\,B \to BYPASS\,A \to AUX}\)
    • The cryostat is pumped from the still, the QSB valve is opened, and use the ROOTS pump, also the BYPASS B and A are open, and finally reach the auxiliary pump;
  • \(\rm{condenser \to v_{condenser} \to v3 \to v2 \to v6 \to v7 \to BYPASSofSTILL}\) \(\rm{\to QSB \to ROOTS \to BYPASS\,B \to BYPASS\,A \to AUX}\)
    • Use BYPASSofSTILL to pump the condenser line of cryostat, and also use the ROOTS pump;
  • \(\rm{trap \to v1A \to v2 \to v6 \to v7 \to BYPASSofSTILL}\) \(\rm{\to QSB \to ROOTS \to BYPASS\,B \to BYPASS\,A \to AUX}\)
    • We opened the 1A valve and we pump the liquid nitrogen trap at the same time.

Cold finger inserting

  • We inserted the liquid Helium delivery line from the liquefier into the cryostat MB.

Routine leak check

Leak check between MB and OVC

  • After the turbo was ready, we opened the valve of the OVC and, using the LD (Leak Detector), checked the He leaking rate of the OVC.
  • We waited for the OVC vacuum to almost reach its limit.
  • Using the 1KPOT pump, we pumped the MB and then filled the MB with He (gradually, per 200 mbar, while checking the leak rate of the leak detector).
  • Closed the valve of the OVC.

Natural leak rate of MB

  • We kept the MB isolated and checked the MB leak rate with reference to pressure changes.

    It was 16 mbar/min.

Vacuum baseline of MB

  • At the same time, the auxiliary pump and 1KPOT pump were used to pump MB, and the level of baseline can be achieved reached 1.0 * 10^-1 mbar, read from P4.

Leak check between MB and IVC

  • Opened the valve of the IVC, pumped the MB, and then filled the MB with He (gradually, per 200 mbar, while checking the leak rate of the leak detector).

Leak check between 1KPOT and IVC

  • Using a 1KPOT pump, pumped 1KPOT and then filled the 1KPOT with He (gradually, per 200 mbar, while checking the leak rate of the leak detector).

DU capillary flow test

Please check that the He flows regularly through the condenser line of the DU.

  • In order to make this test, pressurize the still volume (read at G2) with He gas (5.0 is enough) from a bottle and through
    • \(\rm{v11 \to v6 \to v7 \to BYPASSofSTILL}\).

Make sure that the condenser BYPASS is closed (G3 should not increase while G2 increases).

  • But perform compatible measurements, G2 should always arrive precisely at the black tick just above 1000 mbar.
  • Then open v3 (v2-v1A-v1 closed) and measure the pressure increase over time on G3 (take into account the offset).

A suggestion is to measure the increase over a longer period than a minute (like 5 or 10 minutes).

  • The DU capillary flow test must be performed at room temperature, at 77K and at 4K. The reference capillary flow in 2020-2021 are:
    • 3.5 mbar/min @ room T
    • 18 ~ 19 mbar/min IVC @ 77 K, MC @ 110 ~ 100 K (-19 umol/s on \(^{3}\rm{He}\) flow reader)
    • 60 ~ 70 mbar/min IVC @ 5.1 ~ 4.7 K, MC @31.5~24.6 K (-90 ~ -80 umol/s on \(^{3}\rm{He}\) flow reader)
  • We stopped the pumping of cryostat, turned off the ROOTS pump.
  • Closed the condenser BYPASS.
  • We filled the cryostat with He-2 from still, pumped gas from the condenser. That means we started the counter flow of the circulation path.
  • We closed v1 and we suspended the counter flow of the mixture circulation path, which means we performed the capillary test.
  • After that we restored the counter flow of the circulation path.

Leak check DU -> IVC

  • The leak check DU -> IVC must be performed at room temperature, at 77K and at 4K and comes for free monitoring the IVC leak rate while making the capillary flow test (for which you have to pressurize the still with 1 bar of He).

Since is a good practice to counter flow the capillary during a cooldown, this test comes for free in each moment of the cooldown when you are pumping the IVC with the leak detector.
Reaching a good leak rate in IVC is not easy if you use He as exchange gas also from 300K down to 77K.

A reference value of leak rate in IVC is less than few \(10^{-7} \ \rm{mbar*l/s}\) while cooling down.

Flow test 1Kpot needle valves

  • Filled 1KPOT with He-1, and test the flow rate of low-impedance and high-impedance needle valves respectively.
  • Then filled the MB and 1KPOT with He-1.

IVC filling with \(\rm{N}_{2}\)

  • Redo a capillary test
  • We stopped pumping of cryostat. We changed the path of the gas to provide He-2 from still to cryostat using BYPASSofSTILL. We also used valve 1 to pump from the condenser.
  • We filled the 1KPOT with He-1;
    • filled the MB with nitrogen;
    • kept the IVC at 20 mbar of nitrogen.

MB filling with LN

  • We raised the LHe transfer pipe a bit.
  • We opened the valve between the liquefier and the MB, and performed a counter flow from the MB to the getter.
    • When the pressure of MB was found to be oscillating, which means that the liquid nitrogen began to transfer. We controlled the pressure of MB around 890 mbar.
  • During the transfer of liquid nitrogen, we performed two capillary tests by closing v1.
  • We also stopped the counter flow of the liquefier.
  • We disconnected the liquid nitrogen transfer line.

Liquefier preparation

  • We connected the cold box to the turbo, using the “OVC” and “IVC” pipes.
  • We started pumping the cold box, by the turbo and the external pump.
  • After the pumping for one night, we turned off the turbo and stopped the coldbox pumping.
  • After the turbo is stopped, we attached the IVC to the turbo.
  • We turned on GM heads and JT, and using the cooldown bypass.
  • Periodically measure the working point.

re-transferring of liquid nitrogen

  • We inserted the liquid nitrogen transfer line and started the re-transferring of liquid nitrogen into the Dewar.
  • We put some overpressure nitrogen in the MB for re-transferring the liquid nitrogen back to the dewar.

Tests at LN temperature

  • Repeat the contact check.
  • Repeat the capillary test.
  • Repeat the leak check (if you put nitrogen as exchange gas).
    • After the transferring is complete, we use the 1KPOT pump to pump the MB.
    • We connected the IVC to the leak detector.
  • Repeat the needle valve check.
    • Re-pump MB in preparation for flow test for both precision needle valves.
  • We closed the IVC, stopped the turbo and turned off the leak detector.

MB filling with LHe ()

  • start to transfer without waiting for the LHe flame of the boa. The MB and the 1KPot should be in communication and both to recovery. In the IVC there should be some He gas to be used as exchange gas. Moreover, the final part of this helium transfer is different from the refill one because it has to be interrupted at precise conditions.

IVC pumping

1K Pot pumping

Condensation

\(^{3}\rm{He}/^{4}\rm{He}\) mixture circulation

Collect the mixture

Maintenance

1KPOT pump

The 1KPOT pump currently used in Hall-C is for pumping 1KPOT, and occasionally as well for MB.

  • Its model number is D40B and it has gas ballast.
  • Here you can find its manual.

Oil changing

  • Types of oil that can be used:
    • Oil N 62;
    • Oil HE-200.
  • The oil grades N 62 and HE-200 are interchangeable.
    • Caution: Only use the kind of oil specified by Leybold. Alternative types of oil are specified upon request.
  • On initial start-up, after prolonged idle periods or after an oil change, the specified ultimate pressure cannot be attained until the oil is degassed. This can be done by running the pump for approximately 30 minutes with the intake line closed and the gas ballast valve (7/5) open.

entry.title: The CUORE cryostat: current performance and future upgrade towards CUPID
entry.content:
Author: Shihong Fu\(^{*}\), Jiaxuan Cao, on behalf of the CUORE collaboration and CUPID collaboration

Abstract

  • The CUORE (Cryogenic Underground Observatory for Rare Events) experiment is a ton-scale detector1 , operating at a cryogenic temperature around 10 mK, searching for neutrinoless double-beta decay of \(^{130}\rm{Te}\) and other rare events. It owns today's largest milli-Kelvin infrastructure in the world2. We envision an upgrade of the CUORE cryostat in order to host the new CUPID (CUORE Upgrade with Particle IDentification)3 4 array and read-out system5. The former will account for about 1500 bolometers, each served by a light detector; the latter will consequently lead to ~3 times higher thermal load coming from the CUPID wiring with respect to CUORE.
  • In this poster the cryogenics upgrades will be mainly introduced, with a particular focus on the PT (Pulse Tube) system and wiring thermalizations enhancements.
  • We foresee further improvements dedicated to the abatement of the vibrational noise, which in turn will improve the achievable energy resolution of bolometers. Thanks to the experience provided by CUORE, we can clearly demonstrate the effectiveness of the active Pulse Tube noise cancellation technique6, which will also be strengthened and applied in CUPID.

  1. D. Q. Adams et al. (CUORE Collaboration). CUORE opens the door to tonne-scale cryogenics experiments. Progress in Particle and Nuclear Physics 122, 103902 (2022). ↩

  2. A. D’Addabbo et al.. The CUORE Cryostat. J. Low Temp. Phys. 193, 867–875 (2018). ↩

  3. CUPID Collaboration, CUPID: CUORE (Cryogenic Underground Observatory for Rare Events) Upgrade with Particle IDentification arXiv:1504.04599 ↩

  4. CUPID Collaboration, Optimization of the first CUPID detector module arXiv:2202.06279 ↩

  5. CUPID Collaboration, Toward CUPID-1T arXiv:2203.08386 ↩

  6. V. Dompè, C. Bucci, L. Canonica, A. D’Addabbo, S. Di Domizio, G. Fantini, P. Gorla, L. Marini, A. Nucciotti, I. Nutini, C. Rusconi, B. Schmidt, B. Welliver. The CUORE Pulse Tube Noise Cancellation Technique. J. Low Temp. Phys. 200, 286–294 (2020). ↩

entry.title: Diana learning memorandum
entry.content:
Criteria for decision of Energy_OF_WoH

In most of the channels, both estimators (Energy_OF & Energy_OF_WoH) are valid.

  • In this case, we begin by assuming Energy_OF as the default,
  • But define a set of criteria to decide when Energy_OF_WoH is preferred.

We define two quantities, a figure of merit (\(W \eqref{eq: WDef}\)), and significance (\(Z \eqref{eq: ZDef}\)), where:

\[\begin{equation} W \equiv \frac{\sigma_{\rm{OF\_WoH}}^{2} E_{\rm{OF}}^{2}} {\sigma_{\rm{OF}}^{2} E_{\rm{OF\_WoH}}^{2}} \label{eq: WDef} \end{equation} \]

And

\[\begin{equation} Z \equiv \frac{1-W} {\sigma_{W}} \label{eq: ZDef} \end{equation} \]

Here:

  • \(\sigma_{\rm{OF}}\) (or \(\sigma_{\rm{OF\_WoH}}\)) is the RMS of the measured pulse amplitudes of events on the Ch-D as measured using Energy_OF (or Energy_OF_WoH).
  • \(E_{\rm{OF}}\) (or \(E_{\rm{OF\_WoH}}\)) is the exposure for the Ch-D, measured as the product of the detector mass and the live time.

In general,

  • Smaller values for the energy resolution
  • And larger values for the exposure

are preferred for the best sensitivity.

We chose threshold values for \(W\) and \(Z\) to establish the criteria for selecting an alternative energy estimator for a given channel.

  • A value of \(W < 1\) indicates that the channel performs better with the alternative energy estimator (Energy_OF_WoH),
  • While \(Z > 1\) indicates that the value of \(W\) is “significant” with respect to the width of the distribution of \(W\) (i.e., \(\sigma_{W} \eqref{eq: sigmaWCal}\)), calculated with direct propagation of errors for the specified Ch-D:
\[\begin{equation} \sigma_{W} = \left[ \left( \sigma_{\sigma_{Y}^{2}}^{2} / \sigma_{Y}^{2} \right)^{2} + \left( \sigma_{\sigma_{X}^{2}}^{2} / \sigma_{X}^{2} \right)^{2} - 2 \left( \sigma_{\sigma_{Y}^{2}}^{2} / \sigma_{Y}^{2} \right) \left( \sigma_{\sigma_{X}^{2}}^{2} / \sigma_{X}^{2} \right) \rho_{X2Y2} \right]^{1/2} \times \left( \sigma_{Y}^{2} / \sigma_{X}^{2} \right) \label{eq: sigmaWCal} \end{equation} \]

Where:

\[\begin{equation} \begin{aligned} \sigma_{\sigma_{Y}^{2}}^{2} &= \operatorname{Var}{( \operatorname{Var}{(Y)} )} \\ \sigma_{\sigma_{X}^{2}}^{2} &= \operatorname{Var}{( \operatorname{Var}{(X)} )} \\ \sigma_{Y}^{2} &= \operatorname{Var}{(Y)} \\ \sigma_{X}^{2} &= \operatorname{Var}{(X)} \\ \rho_{X2Y2} &= { \frac{\operatorname{Cov}{(X^{2},Y^{2})}} {Y_{M4}X_{M4}} }^{1/2} \end{aligned} \label{eq: sigmaXYDef} \end{equation} \]

And:

\[\begin{equation} \begin{aligned} \operatorname{Var}{(X)} &= \frac{\sum {{\left( X_{i} - \bar{X} \right)}^{2}}} {N-1} \\ X_{M4} &= \frac{\sum {{\left( X_{i} - \bar{X} \right)}^{4}}} {N} \\ \operatorname{Cov}{(X^{2},Y^{2})} &= \frac{\sum {{\left( \left( X_{i} - \bar{X} \right) \left( Y_{i} - \bar{Y} \right) \right)}^{2}}} {N} \end{aligned} \label{eq: VarXDef} \end{equation} \]

for \(N\) entries in the \({}^{208}\rm{Tl}\) peak.

  • This cut on \(Z\) is implemented to avoid cutting on statistical fluctuations, which can lead to a bias.

Decision:

  • For channels with both \(W < 1\) and \(Z > 1\), Energy_OF_WoH was chosen as the energy estimator.
  • Channels without heaters and channels for which the variable Energy_OF was invalid were also assigned to use Energy_OF_WoH.
  • All others defaulted to Energy_OF.
  • Channels for which both estimators were invalid were removed from the analysis.

entry.title: Liquid Helium refill memorandum
entry.content:
1. Set the level reader mode to "10 s” on the software
    • Set the level mode in “fast” mode
  2. Liquid Helium can preparation
    • Connect the Helium gas tube from He-1 bottle to the can
      • (Remember to clean the entire connector)
    • Insert the liquid Helium transfer line (long one or short one)
  3. Open V3 valve (the red one on liquefier panel)
    • (It is the compressor bypass)
  4. Open Main Bath to the CRESST balloon
    • (Red valve to balloon in pumping room + black valve behind the main panel)
  5. Plug the “BOA” into the liquid Helium transfer line on the top of the can
  6. Reduce the liquefier inlet flow down to 3.6 ~ 3.7
  7. Start the liquid Helium refill
    1. Keep 20 ~ 30 mbar over-pressure in the liquid Helium can
    2. Open the transfer line needle valve with 1/2 turn
    3. Wait for the flame
    4. Insert the “BOA” in the liquid Helium transfer line on the side of cryostat
      • You will see the pressure of Main Bath going up
      • (The best is just below the black sign)
    5. Start chronometer
      • After 12 ~ 15 min, you will see the pressure of Main Bath going down in the range 1000 ~ 950 mbar
      • (This means you are transferring liquid Helium)
    6. Open completely the transfer line needle valve
    7. Keep the over-pressure in the can in the range 100 c~ 150 mbar
  8. Stop the liquid Helium refill when reach at ~82% and wait 5 min more
  9. Close safety valve on the can
  10. Close Main Bath to the CRESST balloon
    • (Red valve to balloon in pumping room + black valve behind the main panel)
    • Make sure that the pressure of Main Bath stay similar
  11. Restore “900 s” reading and “slow” mode on level meter
  12. Start to progressively close V3
    • Keep the flow meter ball below 35
  13. When V3 is completely closed, wait Main Bath evaporation flow recover below ~14
  14. Start increasing the liquefier inlet until ~9.00
  15. Remove the “BOA” and the Helium transfer line from the can
  16. Remove the Helium gas line from the can and remember to close the He-1 bottle
